awd_titl_txt: Development of Computer Graphic Visualization Aids for the  Undergraduate Chemistry Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration: This project will use workstation-quality computer graphics to aid              in the visualization of concepts in the undergraduate chemistry                 curriculum.  It focuses on visual presentations and real-time                   visual manipulations.  Examples of subjects include atomic and                  molecular orbitals, molecular geometry, organic dynamics and                    structure, docking of drug molecules, proteins, and other                       biological macromolecules, polymer structure and stereochemistry,               and crystal structures and Miller index planes.  Certain concepts               and visualization programs will be developed for (or adapted for                use on) personal computers coupled with videotapes, laser                       videodiscs, and other media so that the images can be used in                   chemistry lectures, in student tutorials, and for open-ended                    inquiry.  The project aims to have broad impact on and utility for              undergraduate chemistry curricula nationally.  This project was                 funded equally by the Division of Undergraduate Science,                        Engineering, and Mathematics Education, and the Division of                     Chemistry.
